info.meta: How to set up highly available NFS storage using DRBD, LVM and &pace; in a two-node cluster
Set up highly available NFS storage

revdescription.para: Updated for the initial release of &productname; &productnumber;.

sect1.title: Usage scenario
sect1.para: This document helps you set up a highly available NFS server. The cluster used for the highly available NFS storage has the following properties:

listitem.para: Two nodes: &node1; (IP: &subnetI;.1) and &node2; (IP: &subnetI;.2), connected to each other via network.

Two floating, virtual IP addresses (&nfs-vip-hawk; and &nfs-vip-exports;), allowing clients to connect to a service no matter which physical node it is running on. One IP address is used for cluster administration with &hawk2;, and the other IP address is used exclusively for the NFS exports.
SBD used as a &stonith; fencing device to avoid split-brain scenarios. &stonith; is mandatory for the HA cluster.
Failover of resources from one node to the other if the active host breaks down (active/passive setup).
Local storage on each node. The data is synchronized between the nodes using DRBD on top of LVM.
A file system exported through NFS and a separate file system used to track the NFS client states.

sect1.para: After installing and setting up the basic two-node cluster, and extending it with storage and cluster resources for NFS, you will have a highly available NFS storage server.

sect1.title: Creating DRBD devices
sect1.para: This section describes how to set up DRBD devices on top of LVM. Using LVM as a back-end of DRBD has the following benefits:

listitem.para: Easier setup than with LVM on top of DRBD.
Easier administration in case the LVM disks need to be resized or more disks are added to the volume group.

sect1.para: The following procedures result in two DRBD devices: one device for the NFS exports, and a second device to track the NFS client states.

sect1.title: Creating cluster resources
sect1.para: The following procedures describe how to configure the resources required for a highly available NFS cluster.

varlistentry.term: DRBD primitive and promotable clone resources

listitem.para: These resources are used to replicate data. The promotable clone resource is switched to and from the primary and secondary roles as deemed necessary by the cluster resource manager.
These resources manage the file system that will be exported, and the file system that will track NFS client states.
This resource manages the NFS server daemon.
This resource is used to export the directory /srv/nfs/share to clients.

The initial installation creates an administrative virtual IP address for &hawk2;. Create another virtual IP address exclusively for NFS exports. This makes it easier to apply security restrictions later.
The following configuration examples assume that &nfs-vip-exports; is the virtual IP address to use for an NFS server which serves clients in the &subnetI;.x/24 subnet.
The service exports data served from /srv/nfs/share.
Into this export directory, the cluster mounts an ext4 file system from the DRBD device /dev/drbd1. This DRBD device sits on top of an LVM logical volume named /dev/nfs/share.
The DRBD device /dev/drbd0 is used to share the NFS client states from /var/lib/nfs. This DRBD device sits on top of an LVM logical volume named /dev/nfs/state.

sect2.para: Create a cluster resource to manage the DRBD devices, and a promotable clone to allow this resource to run on both nodes:

procedure.title: Creating a DRBD resource for NFS

step.para: Start the crm interactive shell:
Create a primitive for the DRBD configuration nfs:
step.screen: &prompt.crm.conf;primitive drbd-nfs ocf:linbit:drbd \ params drbd_resource="nfs" \ op monitor interval=15 role=Promoted \ op monitor interval=30 role=Unpromoted

step.para: Create a promotable clone for the drbd-nfs primitive:

The nfs_server_scope must be the same on all nodes in the cluster that run the NFS server, but this is not set by default. All clusters using &suse; software can use the same scope, so we recommend setting the value to SUSE.

warning.title: Low lease time can cause loss of file state
warning.para: NFS clients regularly renew their state with the NFS server. If the lease time is too low, system or network delays can cause the timer to expire before the renewal is complete. This can lead to I/O errors and loss of file state.

NFSV4LEASETIME is set on the NFS server in the file /etc/sysconfig/nfs. The default is 90 seconds. If lowering the lease time is necessary, we recommend a value of 60 or higher. We strongly discourage values lower than 30.

sect2.title: Creating an NFS export resource
sect2.para: Create a cluster resource to manage the NFS exports:

step.para: Create a primitive for the NFS exports:
step.screen: &prompt.crm.conf;primitive exportfs-nfs exportfs \ params directory="/srv/nfs/share" \ options="rw,mountpoint" clientspec="192.168.1.0/24" \ op monitor interval=30s timeout=90s
step.para: The value of op monitor timeout must be higher than the value of stonith-timeout. To find the stonith-timeout value, run crm configure show and look under the property section.

important.title: Do not set wait_for_leasetime_on_stop=true
important.para: Setting this option to true in a highly available NFS setup can cause unnecessary delays and loss of locks.
The default value for wait_for_leasetime_on_stop is false. There is no need to set it to true when /var/lib/nfs and nfsserver are configured as described in this guide.
